docs.text: WRCCDC Preparation Warning Keep in mind that for now, this is all written by a guy who has very little clue what he's doing, so take everything with a grain of salt. That said, any corrections and suggestions would be much appreciated through GitHub issues and/or pull requests. Hey all! If you're looking to prepare for the WRCCDC competition, you've come to the right place. Let's get you started by setting up your system
docs.title: WRCCDC Preparation

docs.text: SSH is a secure 1 remote shell access program. Read man ssh.1 for more info. Quick Reference Log on to a remote host # <user> the REMOTE user account # <hostname> hostname or ip address # [port] optional custom port number (default 22) ssh <user>@<hostname> [-p <port>] ssh admin@10.100.23.2 Copy your keys to a host (streamlines and secures logon) May require a package to be downloaded for the commands # Only run this if you have not generated a key before # or if you know what you're doing :D ssh-keygen # follow the defaults # Similar syntax to ssh(1) ssh-copy-id <user>@<hostname> # Manual method: # You may need to mkdir .ssh on the remote system # MAKE SURE YOU'RE COPYING the .pub key!!! scp ~/.ssh/id_*****.pub '<user>@<hostname>:~/.ssh' Notes Most (all?) of the linux competition servers have been using OpenSSH, which is pretty simple to configure . Alpine might have been using Dropbear (?) Not sure how to configure ssh on Windows. Probably doable through the AD interface. Unfortunately, as with anything, it's only as secure as it's configured to be ↩
docs.title: Ssh

docs.text: Log on to a remote host # <user> the REMOTE user account # <hostname> hostname or ip address # [port] optional custom port number (default 22) ssh <user>@<hostname> [-p <port>] ssh admin@10.100.23.2 Copy your keys to a host (streamlines and secures logon) May require a package to be downloaded for the commands # Only run this if you have not generated a key before # or if you know what you're doing :D ssh-keygen # follow the defaults # Similar syntax to ssh(1) ssh-copy-id <user>@<hostname> # Manual method: # You may need to mkdir .ssh on the remote system # MAKE SURE YOU'RE COPYING the .pub key!!! scp ~/.ssh/id_*****.pub '<user>@<hostname>:~/.ssh'
docs.title: Quick Reference

docs.text: Most (all?) of the linux competition servers have been using OpenSSH, which is pretty simple to configure . Alpine might have been using Dropbear (?) Not sure how to configure ssh on Windows. Probably doable through the AD interface. Unfortunately, as with anything, it's only as secure as it's configured to be ↩
docs.title: Notes

docs.text: iptables are a bare-bones kernel-level firewall and packet filter service. Deprecated on many "modern" distros, you will find them in use primarily on Alpine systems. Quick Reference
docs.title: Iptables

docs.text: the net command is a versatile utility for managing local and network resources. Common Operations net user - list and manage local users net user <UserName> {<Password> | *} net user <UserName> {<Password> | *} /add net user <UserName> /delete net localgroup - manage local groups net localgroup <GroupName> <Name> {/add | /delete} manage Administrators and Remote Desktop Users user group affiliations net localgroup Administrators JohnDoe /add net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" AliceLidell /delete
docs.title: Net

docs.text: net user <UserName> {<Password> | *} net user <UserName> {<Password> | *} /add net user <UserName> /delete
docs.title: net user - list and manage local users

docs.text: net localgroup <GroupName> <Name> {/add | /delete} manage Administrators and Remote Desktop Users user group affiliations net localgroup Administrators JohnDoe /add net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" AliceLidell /delete
docs.title: net localgroup - manage local groups

docs.text: active directory (or AD for short) is a domain service managing all sorts of things on Windows.
docs.title: Active directory

docs.text: mailcow is an email suite based on docker Default Logins username password admin moohoo
docs.title: Mailcow

docs.text: SQL is a standard interface language for relational databases. MySQL has been the most prevalent implementation found in past competitions. Quick Reference System Determine which sql program is running ps aux | grep sql Log into a MySQL server ( --help and cli docs ) # Login as <username>. Will prompt for a password mysql -u <username> -p MySQL supports batch execution and plays nice with redirection mysql < batch-file > mysql.out Example List default creds and also where to find them if they have been changed Database List databases SHOW DATABASES; Find any PII (add / remove clauses as needed) SELECT TABLE_SCHEMA, TABLE_NAME, COLUMN_NAME FROM information_schema.COLUMNS WHERE COLUMN_NAME LIKE '%user%' OR COLUMN_NAME LIKE '%pass%' OR COLUMN_NAME LIKE '%cred%' OR COLUMN_NAME LIKE '%secret%' OR COLUMN_NAME LIKE '%key%' OR COLUMN_NAME LIKE '%ssn%' OR COLUMN_NAME LIKE '%email%' OR COLUMN_NAME LIKE '%phone%' OR COLUMN_NAME LIKE '%address%'; Common examples from MySQL Notes INFORMATION_SCHEMA is your best friend when searching for specific info in a large pile of databases and tables. It functions as a "meta-table", meaning it holds information on all of the other tables. LIKE and GLOB are similarly extremely useful for quick searching. Resources W3Schools - pretty good. Can serve as a concise and quick-to-scan reference, or a longer-winded tutorial when you have the time SQLZoo - practice your skills here
docs.title: SQL

docs.text: Determine which sql program is running ps aux | grep sql Log into a MySQL server ( --help and cli docs ) # Login as <username>. Will prompt for a password mysql -u <username> -p MySQL supports batch execution and plays nice with redirection mysql < batch-file > mysql.out Example List default creds and also where to find them if they have been changed
docs.title: System
